pullRequest.body:
Consider direct limits `lim G` and `lim G'` with direct system `f` and `f'` respectively, any
family of linear maps `gᵢ : Gᵢ ⟶ G'ᵢ` such that `g ∘ f = f' ∘ g` induces a linear map
`lim G ⟶ lim G'`. When `gᵢ`'s are equivalence, so is the induced. Similarly for direct limits of groups and rings

This PR is splitted from #8473

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

LGTM, sorry for the delay
bors merge

I thought a bit about the possibility of using the general CategoryTheory.Limits APIs, e.g. [CategoryTheory.Limits.colim](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/Limits/HasLimits.html#CategoryTheory.Limits.colim) (this is for colimit objects chosen by the axiom of choice, so we'd need to build a version with arbitrary designated colimit objects like the DirectLimits here (using [CategoryTheory.Limits.IsColimit.map](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/Limits/IsLimit.html#CategoryTheory.Limits.IsColimit.map)). In addition, we'd need to lift the `G i` to a universe higher than the indexing type `ι`, which means we still need a version of `congr` with `e : (i : ι) → G i ≃+* G' i :=` [ULift.ringEquiv](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Ring/ULift.html#ULift.ringEquiv) etc. In the end, it won't save any work from this PR.

bors d=@alreadydone

Thanks!
This looks great, thanks! I think I'll probably have one more round of style comments tomorrow, (or I might just make them myself)

bors d=@alreadydone

Thanks!

LGTM, sorry for the delay
bors merge

I thought a bit about the possibility of using the general CategoryTheory.Limits APIs, e.g. [CategoryTheory.Limits.colim](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/Limits/HasLimits.html#CategoryTheory.Limits.colim) (this is for colimit objects chosen by the axiom of choice, so we'd need to build a version with arbitrary designated colimit objects like the DirectLimits here (using [CategoryTheory.Limits.IsColimit.map](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/Limits/IsLimit.html#CategoryTheory.Limits.IsColimit.map)). In addition, we'd need to lift the `G i` to a universe higher than the indexing type `ι`, which means we still need a version of `congr` with `e : (i : ι) → G i ≃+* G' i :=` [ULift.ringEquiv](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Ring/ULift.html#ULift.ringEquiv) etc. In the end, it won't save any work from this PR.

I think we're in danger of semantically satiating `map` here; why not use the same name as you did in the docstring:
```suggestion
def map (g : (i : ι) → G i →ₗ[R] G' i) (hg : ∀ i j h, g j ∘ₗ f i j h = f' i j h ∘ₗ g i) :
    DirectLimit G f →ₗ[R] DirectLimit G' f' :=
  lift _ _ _ _ (fun i ↦ of _ _ _ _ _ ∘ₗ g i) fun i j h g ↦ (isEmpty_or_nonempty ι).elim
    (fun _ ↦ Subsingleton.elim _ _) fun _ ↦ by
      have eq1 := LinearMap.congr_fun (hg i j h) g
      simp only [LinearMap.coe_comp, Function.comp_apply] at eq1 ⊢
      rw [eq1, of_f]
```

Same throughout. In the `comp` lemmas, you can use `g\_1` and `g\_2` for the two families.
done

```suggestion
@[simp] lemma map_id [IsDirected ι (· ≤ ·)] :
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
family of equivalences `eᵢ : Gᵢ ≅ G'ᵢ` such that `e ∘ f = f' ∘ e` induces an equivalence
`lim G ≅ lim G'`.
-/
def congr [IsDirected ι (· ≤ ·)]
    (e : (i : ι) → G i ≃ₗ[R] G' i) (he : ∀ i j h, e j ∘ₗ f i j h = f' i j h ∘ₗ e i) :
```
every `equiv` has been changed to `e` (I think)
`functorial` might be a good name for these sections
thanks for the suggestion
